msDesc.head: Nicholas of Cusa, Antonius Barzizius, Heimericus de Campo, Campanus of Novara; Germany (mostly Aachen), c. 1451-5

physDesc.p: A composite volume, mainly of theological and mathematical works by Nicholas of Cusa, mostly written at Aachen between 1451 and 1455.

supportDesc.foliation: 1–24, 25a–f, 26–33, 34a–c, 35–48, 49a–b, 50–59, 60a–b, 61–102 in 19th(?)-century pencil; formerly blank leaves foliated 25b, 25c, etc. in the 20th century.

handDesc.handNote: By several scribes, including Petrus de Ercklentz, canon of Aachen, and Johannes Scoblant (alias Jean Scoblaut), also of Aachen; parts I and II appear to have been rubricated by the same scribe; part III has no rubrics or coloured initials.

binding.p: Late 17th century, probably c. 1695/6 (see Provenance). Sewn on five cords laced into pasteboards covered with speckled brown leather, each cover with a blind-tooled single outer filet and a central panel with a fleuron at each corner; the edges of the leaves speckled red; no pastedowns.

history.provenance: Iohannes Scoblant, in addition to writing parts E-G, added notes to part D and perhaps assembled the volume in its current form. On him see Acta Cusana. Quellen zur Lebensgeschichte des Nikolaus von Kues, Felix Meiner Verlag, Hamburg 2016, no. 2325, with references; Manuscrits dates conserves en Belgique, III (1978), no. 283
Unidentified owner(s): inscribed ‘43’ (fol. 1r, top left) and ‘31’ (fol. 1r, upper right).

Inscribed with a list of contents by a 16th-cent. English hand (Dee?) (fol. 1r); the placement of the inscription here, rather than on a flyleaf or pastedown, suggests that the volume had no binding at the time.

John Dee (1527–1609), with his marginal annotations, especially in part III; R. J. Roberts and A. G. Watson, John Dee’s library catalogue (London, 1990), no. M145 (superseding M. R. James, Lists of manuscripts formerly owned by Dr. John Dee, Supplement to the Bibliographical Society’s Transactions, 1 (Oxford, 1921), p. 30 Fr. 145). The first item in Dee’s catalogue entry M145 is ‘Alberti Magni Magia naturalis et vera’; as Roberts and Watson note there is no sign that anything is missing from the present volume.

Inscribed with a list of contents by a 17th(?)-cent. English hand (Maitland?), ‘These are some pieces of Cardinal Cusanus’s works, and are printed; Except a short comedy in the midle [sic] of this book’ (fol. 1r).

John Maitland (1616–1682), first duke of Lauderdale; offered in the posthumous sale of his library: Bibliotheca instructissima ex bibliothecis … cui adjicitur Bibliotheca manuscripta Lauderdaliana …, Jo. Bullord in Tom’s Coffeehouse, London, 25 January 169½, lot 35 (reprinted as ‘Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum e bibliotheca D. Joannis ducis de Lauderdale, M.DC.XCII’, in The Bannatyne Miscellany, II (Edinburgh, 1836), pp. 151–58, at 155); the list of contents in the auction catalogue matches the list inscribed on fol. 1r (which was subsequently cropped by the binder).

Stephen Bate (1648/9–1714), rector of Horsmonden (diocese of Rochester) from 1673 until his death [Foster, Alumni Oxon. gives his death as 1724, but theclergydatabase.org.uk as 1714]; received from John Maitland in 1694 and given two years later to his uncle; inscribed, ‘Viro admodum Reverendo Johanni Wallisio S T D et in Academia Oxoniensi professori Saviliano dono dedit Stephanus Bate Rector de Horsmonden in agro Cantiano: E Scriptis Domini Ducis de Lauderdale, Anno 1694’ (fol. 2r; the placement of this inscription suggests that the MS. was not yet bound).

John Wallis (1616–1703), Savilian Professor of Geometry at Oxford University. ‘An Extract of a Letter from Dr. Wallis, of May 4. 1697, Concerning the Cycloeid Known to Cardinal Cusanus, about the Year 1450; and to Carolus Bovillus about the Year 1500’, Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, 19, no. 229 (June 1697), 561–66, describing the present MS. at 563–66 (for a discussion of Wallis’s use of the MS. see R. Klibansky, ‘Nicolas de Cues, Charles de Bovelles et la cycloïde’, in Correspondance du P. Marin Mersenne, religieux Minime, XIV: 1646, ed. C. de Waard and A. Beaulieu (Paris, 1980), pp. 358–62).
history.acquisition: Given to the Savile Library in 1696: inscribed ‘Savilianæ Bibliothecæ Mathematicæ Oxoniæ dedit Johannes Wallis 1696’ (fol. ii verso; the placement of this inscription shows that the MS. was bound by this date); ‘MS No. 55’ (fol. ir; cf. spine).

recordHist.source: Description (May 2021) by Peter Kidd, edited by Matthew Holford. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue. Summary Catalogue, Vol. 5, p. 185 Summary Catalogue, Vol. 5, p. 186

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

msItem.rubric: Inchoant capitula Ydeote de Mente. Capitulum primum
msItem.incipit: Quomodo philosophus ad ydiotam ut proficeret de mentis natura accessit
msItem.explicit: Quo mens nostra sit inmortalis et incorruptabilis
msItem.bibl: Nicolai de Cusa Opera omnia, V: Idiota de sapientia, de mente, de staticis experimentis, ed. by R. Steiger and L. Baur, with Appendices by R. Klibansky (Hamburg, 1983; being a partial revision of the 1937 Leipzig edition by L. Baur), pp. 83–84, and describing the present MS. at pp. lv–lvi (siglum ‘Sa.’)

msItem.rubric: Capitulum primum quomodo philosophus ad ydiotam ut de mentis natura accessit
msItem.incipit: Multis ob jubileum Romam mira devotione accurentibus
msItem.explicit: hoc diuturno colloquio miro desiderio incitatas feliciter perduci Amen.
msItem.colophon: In monasterio Vallis Castri seu Caste [Val di Castro, near Ancona] ordinis Camaldunensis ubi sanctus Romualdus capud ordinis sepultus est prope Fabricium in Marchia Anchonitana. Anno Domini. 1450. die 23 Augusti finivi conceptum de mente N. card. sancti Petri ad Vincula.
msItem.note: A copy: this colophon occurs in several MSS.
msItem.bibl: ed. Steiger and Baur, pp. 85–218. Also printed (with facing German translation) by L. Gabriel, Nikolaus von Kues, Philosophisch-theologischen Schriften, III (Vienna, 1967), pp. 480–609.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in brown plummet for two columns; fols. 1r–10v with an increasing number of lines, from 35 to 41; thereafter with 35–37 lines. Ruled space 175 130 , with 23-5 mm. between columns.

handDesc.handNote: Hybrid gothic script; each of the three quires by different scribes; fols. 1r–10v written by Petrus de Ercklentz, who in the autumn of 1451 was with Nicholas de Cusa at Aachen (according to Kiblanski in Steiger and Baur, 1983, p. lv); rubrics in more formal script; thereafter more cursive and in darker ink; fols. 11-20 with many looped/cursive forms.

history.origin: 15th century, middle (after August 1450) Germany: very probably Aachen, 1451, as part B

msItem.author: Nicholas of Cusa
msItem.title: De staticis experimentis
msItem.incipit: Frequentabat consortium ydeote orator ille Romanus. ut aliquando viri illius conceptus. qui sibi grati erant. audiret.
msItem.explicit: Si me amas diligens esto et vale.
msItem.colophon: (copied from exemplar) 1450. 9a 7bris Fabriani complevi N. cardinali sancti Petri.
(scribal) Finivi Aquisgrani [i.e. Aachen] Anno domini 1451 8a sancti Leopardi [i.e. 7 October: the octave of the 30 September feast of St Leopardus, whose relics were at Aachen]
msItem.bibl: ed. Steiger and Baur, 1983, pp. 221–41 (Baur, 1937, pp. 119–39); Gabriel, pp. 612–47.
msItem.note: Added note: ‘mathematicus de iudicio sortilegorum fuit in duren [i.e. Düren] Anno 1449’ (fol. 33r, lower left margin)
Fols. 34a verso – 35b verso are ruled, otherwise blank.

supportDesc.support: Paper; watermark apparently as part A.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in red-brown plummet for two columns of 36–37 lines. Ruled space c. 175 130 , c. 25mm. between columns.

handDesc.handNote: Hybrid gothic script; rubrics written more formally. Same scribe as part A, fols. 21r-25ra.

msItem.author: Nicholas of Cusa
msItem.title: Epistolae ad Bohemos
msItem.note: Added 16th-cent. heading: Contra Jacobellinos in Bohemia
msItem.incipit: Nicolaus miseratione divina tituli sancti Petri ad vincula sacrosancte Romane ecclesie … Voluit divina pietas ut ordinatione sanctissimi et piissimi pontificis nostri Nicolai pape quinti summe pro vestra ac omnium salute vigilantis
msItem.explicit: Ihesu Christi semper benedicti Amen. Datum in civitate nostra Brixiensis … [11 October 1452] … Nicolai divina providentia pape quinti anno sexto.
msItem.bibl: Nicolai de Cusa Opera omnia, XV.1: Opuscula Bohemica, ed. by S. Nottelmann and I. G. Senger (Hamburg, 2014), pp. 55–98; the present MS. listed at p. xxii no. 17 (siglum ‘Sa’).
msItem.note: Fols. 47–49a should follow fol. 38, which has a 16th/17th-cent. note (by the same hand as fol. 1r, upper margin) ‘hic inserenda sunt tria folia quæ habenetur in fine huius tractatus’; fol. 47 has a corresponding note.

supportDesc.support: Paper. Watermark: bull’s head with nostrils and 6-pointed star (type Piccard Ochsenkopf VII.661-2).
supportDesc.collation: Probably originally two quires of eight leaves, of which the first comprised fols. 35–38 and 47–49a, with 49b left blank, and the second (by a different scribe) comprised fols. 39–46.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled in grey plummet for two columns of c.37 lines. Ruled space c. 180 130 , 20-25 mm. between columns.

handDesc.handNote: Hybrid gothic, by two scribes (cf. Collation), neater but more cursive than the preceding section.

msItem.author: Antonius Barzizius
msItem.title: Cauteriaria
msItem.rubric: Anthonii Barsizii Canteriaria Comedia Incipit argumentum
msItem.incipit: Argument incipit: Salmine consilio datur opera ut amore diu vexati quod optant efficiant
Cum sepe numero mecum ipse consultarim
msItem.rubric: Canterie comedie actus. Incipit primus Scintilla Salamina
msItem.incipit: Nullam profecto legem duriorem severioremque reperiri posse arbitror
msItem.explicit: statim ut omnia parata sint faxo.
msItem.bibl: ed. E. Beutler, ‘Die Comoedia Cauteriaria des Antonio Barzizza’, Forschungen und Texte zur frühhumanistischen Komödie, Mitteilungen aus der Hamburger Staats- und Universitätsbibliothek, 11 (1927), pp. 155–79; cf. P. Rosso, ‘Tradizione testuale ed aree di diffusione della Cauteriaria di Antonio Barzizza’, Humanistica Lovaniensia, 53 (2004), 1–92. Beutler knew of 16 MSS., to which Rosso added two more; neither knew of the present MS.

msItem.incipit: Retulit Johannes de Musschezele clericus Tornacensis diocesis se legisse in romanico Francie (?) quod quedam iuvenis mulier nupta cuidam antiquo
msItem.explicit:
ipsa die Annunciationis 1454. Aquisgrani Jo. Scoblat.
Ita restavi Ego Iohannes predictus

msItem.incipit: (fol. 60ar) Anno Christi 149 fertur quod in Sittarrt [Sittard, near Aachen] vicini fuerunt presbiter quidam et faber cui uxor satis lubrica
msItem.explicit: Mathias de Beeck ipsa nocte sancti Mathie [i.e. 24 Feb.] 1455 Aquisgrani

supportDesc.support: Paper. Watermark: crown (type Piccard Kronen I.327).

layoutDesc.layout: Written in a single column of 36–48 lines; frame-ruled faintly with plummet (?). Ruled space 210 145

handDesc.handNote: Hybrid gothic script; the rubrics more formally written; the final added texts in two much smaller and more cursive hands.

decoDesc.decoNote: The first three initials in plain red with reserved designs; spaces left for others.

history.provenance: In Aachen by 1454/5 when the texts on fols. 59v-60(a)r were added.

msItem.author: Nicholas of Cusa
msItem.title: De mathematicis complementis (Book I)
msItem.rubric: [Guide to rubricator:] De mathematicis complementis Beatissimo papae Nicolao Quinto Nicholaus cardinalis sancti Petri ad vincula
msItem.incipit: Tanta est potestas summi tui pontificatus Nicolae quinte pater beatissime
msItem.explicit: papam appellant in omnium noticiam deducatur
msItem.colophon: Jo. Scoblant Aquisgrani 1454 Februarii die sancti Mathie [i.e. 24 Feb.]
msItem.bibl: Nicolai de Cusa Opera omnia, XX: Scripta mathematica (Hamburg, 2010), pp. 83–110; the present MS. briefly described at pp. xxi–xxii. Cf. Nikolaus von Kues, Werke, I, ed. P. Wilpert (Berlin, 1967), pp. 388–405 line 40.

msItem.author: Heimericus de Campo
msItem.title: Letter to Dietrich van Xanten, dated 14 January 1454
msItem.rubric: Suo singulari amico Magistro Theodorico de Xantis investito de Hasselt generalique domini cardinalis sancti Petri ad vincula commissario. Epistola.
msItem.incipit: Vidi raptim opera de quadracione circuli tam mathematica quam theologica
msItem.explicit: Remitto vobis unum transcriptum manu mea revisum et correctum. optavi id per vos recipi grate. Vale ex Lovanio 14 januarii vester H. de Campo
msItem.bibl: Pr. from this, the only known copy, by F. Hamann, Das Siegel der Ewigkeit: Universalwissenschaft und Konziliarismus bei Heymericus de Campo, Buchreihe der Cusanus-Gesellschaft, 16 (Aschendorff, 2006), p. 340.

msItem.author: Campanus of Novara
msItem.title: De quadratura circuli
msItem.incipit: Aristoteles in eo qui de cathegoriis libro inscribitur sic dicit Quadratura quidem circuli scibilis est
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit quadratura circuli edita a Campano
msItem.incipit: Rem novam mirabilem, quadratura circuli, velud inscriptibilem
msItem.explicit: vere demonstrabilem, nunc in fine seculi.
msItem.bibl: ed. M. Clagett, Archimedes in the Middle Ages, I (Madison, 1964), pp. 588–606 (with English translation on facing pages), not including the final verses, which are also found in Cambridge, UL, MS. Ee. III. 61 and Erfurt, UB, Dep. Erf. CA. 2º 178.
msItem.note: The text is listed, not mentioning the present MS., in O. Weijers, Le travail intellectuel à la Faculté des arts de Paris: textes et maîtres (ca. 1200–1500), II (Turnhout, 1996), pp. 31–32.
Added in a much paler ink than the preceding text, with a few diagrams, mostly marginal.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled in plummet for two columns of c. 35-9 lines. Ruled space c. 180 130 with c. 25 mm. between columns.

handDesc.handNote: Variable hybrid gothic script, perhaps by more than one scribe.

decoDesc.decoNote: Spaces usually not left for the diagrams, which are therefore usually added untidily in margins.

history.provenance: Fols. 61r-68v written at Aachen by Johannes Scoblant, 1454 (colophon, fol. 68v); fols. 68v-70v probably contemporary additions.

msItem.author: Nicholas of Cusa
msItem.title: De theologicis complementis
msItem.incipit: Scripseram proxime de mathematicis ad pontificem nostrum .N. dignissimum et doctissimum papam
msItem.explicit: sed realiter synonymum. Et exit brevis explanatio complementi theologico … ad laudem dei semper benedicti
msItem.colophon: Deo gratias. per me Jo. Scoblaut 1454 Aprilis die 8 [?or 18]
msItem.bibl: Nicolai de Cusa Opera omnia, X: Opuscula II.2a., ed. by A. D. Riemann and C. Bormann (Hamburg, 1994), pp. 3–83; the present MS. briefly described at p. xviii (siglum ‘Sa’).
msItem.note: Added note: (fol. 71r) Confer hæc cum illa prodi Theologiæ in Euclidem
Final note: Hec theologica est omnibus rationabilis dei in qualibet lege nature/figure/gratie discibilis indubitantur presuppositer
msItem.bibl: ed. Riemann and Bormann, op. cit., pp. 84–86.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled in plummet for 2 columns of about 37 lines. Ruled space c. 180 130 , c. 25 mm. between columns

handDesc.handNote: Hybrid gothic script by Jo. Scoblaut; the first word of each chapter in larger and more formal script; spaces left for rubrics.

msItem.author: Nicholas of Cusa
msItem.title: De pace fidei
msItem.incipit: Fuit ex hiis que aput Constantinopolim proxime sevissime acta per Turkorum regem divulgabantur
msItem.explicit: ut in pace creator omnium laudetur in secula benedictus
msItem.bibl: Nicolai de Cusa Opera Omnia, VII: De pace fidei, Cum epistola ad Ioannem de Segobia, ed. by R. Klibansky (Hamburg, 1970), pp. 3–63.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled in plummet for 2 columns of about 37 lines. Ruled space c. 180-5 130 , c. 25 mm. between columns

handDesc.handNote: Hybrid gothic script written by Io. Scoblant; spaces left for rubrics, with cues in the margins.

revisionDesc.change: Description fully revised for Polonsky German digitization project.
James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
